pageContext.claim: “We'll strongly protect Medicare and social security.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump routinely promises to protect Social Security and Medicare, two of the biggest entitlement programs. But there are some reasons to doubt the sincerity of this pledge. In an interview with CNBC in January 2020, Trump had said "At the right time, we will take a look at that," referring to possible reductions in spending on safety net programs, adding that "we're going to look" at cutting Medicare. He as not especially specific or detailed, however. Trump routinely proposes to make spending reductions in Medicare and Social Security but these are mostly proposals borrowed from Barack Obama intended to make the programs more financially stable. At the same time, under Trump, the date for when the Medicare Hospital Insurance (Part A) trust fund will be depleted keeps advancing. The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) in 2020 projected that the trust fund will be exhausted in 2024, a little more than three years away, which is the nearest the fund has come to exhaustion in the 55 years of its existence. If the trust fund is depleted, that means the government would not be able to cover 100 percent of estimated expenses.
